I keep trying to tell my family and friends that viruses 'want' (as much as they want anything) to spread as much as possible. Killing its host is not an evolutionary advantage. If the virus kills its host too quickly then people will take it more seriously, as well as potentially more less time for the virus to spread to others while the host is alive. Typically what you will see (and what sar-scov2 is heading towards) is something like the flu where it spreads every year, but becomes typically less deadly. High infeciton rates, with little host impact is the goal.

What is bad is when a virus transfers to a different type of host (like a bat or monkey), changes a bunch to become successful in that group, and then comes back to humans. When it comes back, it may still be very infectious to humans, but may be more deadly because it is now optomized for this other group.

Now, the other potentially terrible thing that we are seeing is with these new more infectious mutations. Much more infectious, which overloads the hospitals, which then limits care, and more people die; a similar (or more likely lower) percentage of cases are dying... but so many extra cases that the over-all death count is higher.
Except that I am not sure that is exactly what is happening. The R0 of a virus is based on how much the virus is spreading; not how easy a virus can spread. We are still in the midst of reported infections which started back in Christmas and New Years... The issue we may be seeing with the rise in R0 may have a lot more to do with people letting their defences down, and being in close quarters inside, and traveling a lot instead of the virus itself being worse. Many parts of England have given up on enforcing lock-down policies, though I am not sure about Africa. The US has also given up on lockdowns in many areas, which is why we are seeing the numbers that we have right now. I could absolutely be wrong in this, but I really hope I am not, and we will see things calm down a bit in the end of January and heading into feb.

I guess my encouragement is that we should be on the tail end of the holiday infections. With people going back home, and going back to their regular routine with smaller required social circles there is a very good chance the R0 will drop substantially over the next few months... and will drop like a rock in the spring when people can more easily go outdoors again. Hopefully most people will be vaccinated by the end of this summer, and when we hit the fall wave again (and there will be a fall wave), it will hopefully be very small and manageable much like the common flu, and with enough resources to treat people that it will hopefully not be significantly more deadly than the flu.

This is misleading. There is no research that concludes actually better transmissibility. The “viral load” they’ve sampled is from PCR test CT values, which only tell you about the amount of RNA found, and not the amount of functioning viral particles. The correct test in these cases is a plaque assay. On the other hand, the epidemiological data used to “conclude” transmissibility only shows a correlation between the total number of cases and the presence of this variant in them. This does not imply causation, since such data can be simply a consequence of other epidemiological events such as the Founder Effect. A correct test here is hard to formulate, but one option is to do tracking of naive patients and the people they live together with, checking frequently if any got infected and with which variant. If done blindly, and with enough people, the rate at which the whole household gets infected could lead to actual transmissibility data.
